channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: California's troubled unemployment agency needs immediate overhaul, report says
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California should replace outdated technology and overhaul poor policies that have delayed unemployment benefits to those left jobless during the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a strike team appointed by the governor.
item.content:encoded: California should replace outdated technology and overhaul poor policies that have delayed unemployment benefits to those left jobless during the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a strike team appointed by the governor.

media:content.media:description: Joe Marquez, a former sheet metal worker from La Habra, looks for jobs at the One-Stop center in East Los Angeles. The Legislature-approved money will be an immediate lifeline for 76,000 people whose benefits were set to run out April 11.

item.title: L.A. County reports 1,343 new coronavirus cases and 13 additional deaths
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser
item.description: The new report brings the total positive COVID-19 cases to 259,817 countywide. So far, 6,330 people have died in L.A. County from COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: The new report brings the total positive COVID-19 cases to 259,817 countywide. So far, 6,330 people have died in L.A. County from COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: CycleBar employee Nia Freeman takes the temperature of a cyclist before a fitness class outside CycleBar, Tuesday, Sept. 15, 2020, in Culver City, Calif. California fitness centers have filed a lawsuit alleging Gov. Gavin Newsom's measures aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus unfairly target the industry and are demanding they be allowed to reopen. (AP Photo/Chris Pizzello)

item.title: Video shows LAPD officer shooting protester in groin at close range
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Body camera video from protests this summer shows LAPD officers yank a sign from a man and shoot him in the groin with a projectile at close range.
item.content:encoded: Body camera video from protests this summer shows LAPD officers yank a sign from a man and shoot him in the groin with a projectile at close range.

media:content.media:description: Newly-released body-camera footage from protests in Los Angeles this summer shows Los Angeles police officers yank a large protest sign from the hands of a man in a Hollywood intersection, shove him backwards as he puts his hands up, then shoot him in the groin with a projectile at close range.

item.title: Bobcat fire explodes to 93,842 acres, claims homes amid heavy winds; more evacuations ordered
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: As of Saturday, the Bobcat fire had burned more than 93,842 acres and was threatening some desert communities.
item.content:encoded: As of Saturday, the Bobcat fire had burned more than 93,842 acres and was threatening some desert communities.

media:content.media:description: A house on Cima Mesa Road in Juniper Hills burns as the Bobcat fire continues to rage Friday.

item.title: Column: Sharks moving north, redwood growth slowing, mosquitoes biting — this is California's altered state
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: We need to listen to nature's chorus about the alarming effects of climate change and act to reverse it, columnist Steve Lopez writes.
item.content:encoded: We need to listen to nature's chorus about the alarming effects of climate change and act to reverse it, columnist Steve Lopez writes.

media:content.media:description: Place: Monterey Bay Last visited: This fall My perspective: The weather was overcast. --Ann Light, Pacific Grove, Calif. Pictured: a young white shark at the Monterey Bay Aquarium

item.title: California was choked by wildfire smoke. How bad is it for our health?
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza, Joseph Serna
item.description: For weeks, millions of Californians were smothered by smoke from wildfires. Many worry about long-term health impacts.
item.content:encoded: For weeks, millions of Californians were smothered by smoke from wildfires. Many worry about long-term health impacts.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 14: Breya Hodge walks her dog "Sophie" as smoke and ash from the Bobcat fire burning in the Angeles National Forest have blanketed the region for a week, contributing to poor air quality which nearly obscures the tall buildings of downtown Los Angeles September 14, 2020. Current air quality readings are considered unhealthy for sensitive groups according to the Environmental Protection Agency. The bobcat fire is one of more than 25 fires burning in California creating a plume that spanned more than 1,000 miles. Downtown on Monday, Sept. 14, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. suffered deadly heat, yet chairs sat empty at its cooling centers
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Fewer than 300 people used the six centers that were set up at Los Angeles city facilities over the blistering Labor Day holiday weekend.
item.content:encoded: Fewer than 300 people used the six centers that were set up at Los Angeles city facilities over the blistering Labor Day holiday weekend.

media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA - AUGUST 19: Anthony Aco and Troy Sacaguin, left to right, check out the thermometer at Calvary Church in Woodland Hills as it registers 117 degree's Fahrenheit Wednesday afternoon as the Southland's fiercest heat wave entered its second week threatening "excessive heat" and elevated fire danger. Los Angeles on Wednesday, Aug. 19, 2020 in Woodland Hills, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: This new citizen's view of America might help cut through the rancor and division
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: Clemencia Morales from Guatemala just became a new U.S. citizen. She's been thanking America by making thousands of masks and big pots of food to give out for free
item.content:encoded: Clemencia Morales from Guatemala just became a new U.S. citizen. She's been thanking America by making thousands of masks and big pots of food to give out for free

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -SEPTEMBER 18, 2020: Clemencia Morales, who comes from Guatemala and became a U.S. citizen on August 20, 2020, the day after her 65th birthday, is photographed at her home in Los Angeles. In one hand she is holding the American flag that was given to her when she took the oath to become a U.S. citizen at the Federal Building in downtown Los Angeles. In the other hand she is holding one of the over 5000 masks she made from fabric she had around the house and handed out for free to people in Compton as they were standing in line for food. At right is a pottery chime from Guatemala. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In D.A.'s race framed by reform, George Gascón's police career is under a microscope
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: In his bid to become L.A. County's next district attorney, George Gascón has touted his record as a reformer. While many praise his history, questions are being raised about his handling of LAPD.
item.content:encoded: In his bid to become L.A. County's next district attorney, George Gascón has touted his record as a reformer. While many praise his history, questions are being raised about his handling of LAPD.

media:content.media:description: San Francisco Dist. Atty. George Gascon is among the law enforcement officials pushing for "kill switches" on smartphones.

item.title: Criticism of sheriff's performance intensifies, but Villanueva insists he's not concerned
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Some of the people who hold the purse strings and oversee the Sheriff's Department want Sheriff Alex Villanueva out, but he and other elected sheriffs wield substantial power.
item.content:encoded: Some of the people who hold the purse strings and oversee the Sheriff's Department want Sheriff Alex Villanueva out, but he and other elected sheriffs wield substantial power.

media:content.media:description: LYNWOOD, CA - SEPTEMBER 12: Sheriff Alex Villanueva holds a press conference outside the emergency room of St. Francis Medical Center where two L.A. County sheriff's deputies are being treated for after being shot and gravely injured in attack captured on Saturday, Sept. 12, 2020 in Lynwood, CA (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Tsunami' of hotel closures is coming, experts warn
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: The Luxe Rodeo Drive is the first L.A.-area luxury hotel to go out of business because of the pandemic. An unusually high loan delinquency rate may mean more hotel closures are likely to follow.
item.content:encoded: The Luxe Rodeo Drive is the first L.A.-area luxury hotel to go out of business because of the pandemic. An unusually high loan delinquency rate may mean more hotel closures are likely to follow.

media:content.media:description: Rooms are on sale at selected Luxe Hotels in Southern California, including the property at 360 N. Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills.

item.title: Full coverage: Jackie Lacey and George Gascón face off in L.A. County district attorney race
item.description: The November contest between Los Angeles County Dist. Atty. Jackie Lacey and former San Francisco Dist. Atty. George Gascón to oversee the nation's largest prosecutor's office has been framed as a test of appetites for criminal justice reform.
item.content:encoded: With debates about criminal justice reform and police accountability buzzing across the country, the race for Los Angeles County's next top prosecutor may be one of the most important on the ballot in Southern California this November.Jackie Lacey, the county's first Black district attorney and a career prosecutor backed by local law enforcement, is seeking a third term in office, but she will have to fend off a challenge from former San Francisco Dist. Atty. George Gascón, who is considered one of the key figures in a push to elect more progressive prosecutors across the U.S. The race is seen as a referendum on what 21st century criminal justice should look like, one that's been exacerbated after a summer that saw large-scale opposition to the police killings of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor and the shooting of Jacob Blake. Lacey has been faulted by activists for her perceived hesitance to charge police in controversial killings, but Gascón has faced questions about his own record of not filing such charges during his eight years in San Francisco. You can review The Times' coverage of the race here.

media:content.media:description: San Francisco District Attorney George Gascon and Los Angeles County District Attorney Jackie Lacey are competing for Los Angeles District Attorney.

item.title: Governor again overrules parole board recommendation to free ex-Mexican Mafia member
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Rene Enriquez, a Mexican Mafia member who defected 18 years ago and helped law enforcement authorities incarcerate dozens of his onetime confederates, was denied parole for a fifth time.
item.content:encoded: Rene Enriquez, a Mexican Mafia member who defected 18 years ago and helped law enforcement authorities incarcerate dozens of his onetime confederates, was denied parole for a fifth time.

media:content.media:description: Rene Enriquez, a former member of the Mexican Mafia, now speaks before business and police groups about the internal workings of the gang and has become a valuable law enforcement asset – providing expert testimony and other help in scores of cases.

item.title: Magnitude 4.5 earthquake rattles Southern California, but no major damage reported
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Chavez, Dakota Smith, Julia Wick
item.description: A magnitude 4.5 earthquake was reported Friday evening at 11:38 p.m. Pacific time in Rosemead, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 4.5 earthquake was reported Friday evening at 11:38 p.m. Pacific time in Rosemead, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: Want to honor Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg? Show up to vote Nov. 3
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano
item.description: Ginsburg showed me the power of working from a disadvantage — the more they underestimate you, the more satisfying the victory. Her 22-year battle against various cancers was an inspiration for someone who lost his mother just last year to ovarian cancer.
item.content:encoded: Ginsburg showed me the power of working from a disadvantage — the more they underestimate you, the more satisfying the victory. Her 22-year battle against various cancers was an inspiration for someone who lost his mother just last year to ovarian cancer.

media:content.media:description: People lay flowers and light candies outside the Supreme Court Friday, Sept. 18, 2020, in Washington, after the Supreme Court announced that Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg died of metastatic pancreatic cancer at age 87. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon)

item.description: California gained 101,900 jobs in August, mostly due to the temporary hiring of federal census takers.
item.content:encoded: California gained 101,900 jobs in August, mostly due to the temporary hiring of federal census takers.

item.title: Attorney for actor Danny Masterson alleges rape charges are politically motivated
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, James Queally
item.description: Actor Danny Masterson is charged with raping three women at his home between 2001 and 2003. His lawyer claims the charges are politically motivated,
item.content:encoded: Actor Danny Masterson is charged with raping three women at his home between 2001 and 2003. His lawyer claims the charges are politically motivated,

item.title: 'We expect structure loss': Bobcat fire forces more evacuations in Antelope Valley
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith, Dakota Smith
item.description: The blaze, which started Sept. 6, has now chewed through more than 72,000 acres and is rapidly continuing its northeastern expansion.
item.content:encoded: The blaze, which started Sept. 6, has now chewed through more than 72,000 acres and is rapidly continuing its northeastern expansion.

media:content.media:description: Monrovia, CA, September 15, 2020 - Iris, 4, and Castle Snider, 8, look on as flames engulf the hillsides behind their backyard as the Bobcat Fire burns near homes on Oakglade Dr. (Robert Gauthier/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. schools are closed — but there are loopholes for those with money
item.dc:creator: Sonja Sharp, Laura Newberry
item.description: K-12 schools in Los Angeles are not allowed to be open at the moment. Yet many schools have reopened anyway, either by outsourcing their facilities to established providers like the Y, or by rebranding as day camps, which are license-exempt and virtually unregulated in California.
item.content:encoded: K-12 schools in Los Angeles are not allowed to be open at the moment. Yet many schools have reopened anyway, either by outsourcing their facilities to established providers like the Y, or by rebranding as day camps, which are license-exempt and virtually unregulated in California.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE, CA - SEPTEMBER 17, 2020 - - Denecia Boone, a teacher with the YMCA, helps Maya Haldeman, foreground, with an exercise at the Anza Elementary School campus in Torrance on September 17, 2020. Anza Elementary School is one of many schools that are reformatting and rebranding as camps, enrichment programs and daycare, bringing students back to closed campuses for a fee. Torrance Unified School District is one of many that now offers fee-based, in person enrichment for its elementary school students, through the YMCA. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: San Francisco, on cusp of advancing in tiered reopening, will let restaurants serve indoors soon
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Mayor London Breed says indoor dining in limited capacity will be allowed when the city moves into the orange tier, possibly by the end of the month.
item.content:encoded: Mayor London Breed says indoor dining in limited capacity will be allowed when the city moves into the orange tier, possibly by the end of the month.

media:content.media:description: July 14 photo of Sarah Trubnick, owner of The Barrel Room, inside her restaurant in San Francisco. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

item.content:encoded: A front of cold, low-pressure air moving in from the northwest may help clear out some of the wildfire smoke that has been smothering the region.

item.title: Fast-moving Snow fire, sparked by burning car, prompts evacuations near Palm Springs
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Snow fire, which began Thursday and has grown to 2,500 acres, is forcing evacuations and threatening power lines near Palm Springs, officials say.
item.content:encoded: The Snow fire, which began Thursday and has grown to 2,500 acres, is forcing evacuations and threatening power lines near Palm Springs, officials say.

media:content.media:description: WHITEWATER, CA - SEPTEMBER 18, 2020: Elias Lomeli of Desert Hot Springs watches firefighting helicopters refill with water from his car's sunroof as the Snow fire burns in the background off Interstate 10 on September 18, 2020 in Whitewater, California. The fire is 8 miles northwest of Palm Springs and has burned more than 2,500 acres. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'A tsunami of fire': North Complex fire victims couldn't outrun or hide from the flames

media:content.media:description: Butte County, California-Sept. 17, 2020-Margaret Stewart, center, and Ben Arnold, left, both with Los Angeles Fire Department Regional Task Force-9 along with working dog Veya, right, search rural Butte County for victims of the North Complex fire on Sept. 16, 2020. Members of the Los Angeles Fire Department Regional Task Force 9 search rural Butte County with canines for victims of the North Complex fire that has left over a dozen people dead. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

Workers at hospitals owned by Prime Healthcare said they picketed the facilities over the corporation's attempt to cut their sick time and disability even as the employees risk their health treating Covid-19 patients. item.title: UC bans race-based quotas for admissions and hiring, setting limits for possible return of affirmative action
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: University of California regents approved a ban on the use of quotas based on race or gender in admissions and hiring, underscoring their intent to limit how affirmative action would be restored if state voters approve a proposed constitutional amendment allowing it.
item.content:encoded: University of California regents approved a ban on the use of quotas based on race or gender in admissions and hiring, underscoring their intent to limit how affirmative action would be restored if state voters approve a proposed constitutional amendment allowing it.

media:content.media:description: The California Legislature is weighing a proposal to exempt state public college and university admissions from the Proposition 209 ban on affirmative action. Above, protesters are seen in San Francisco demonstrating against Proposition 209 in 2012.

item.title: California workers to get stronger family leave protections under new state law

item.content:encoded: SB 1383 requires employers with five or more workers to offer 12 weeks of unpaid time off to bond with a child or care for a relative starting Jan. 1.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 04: Stephanie, Kevin and their son Kruz Zapata, 2, hang at the Monrovia public library in Monrovia on Friday, Sept. 4, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA.Stephanie's second baby is due in December and Kevin will have job protections in order to take family leave under a bill Gov. Gavin Newsom is expected to sign that will give millions of workers at smaller businesses job protections for parental leave. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 45 charged with poaching marine life from fragile San Pedro tide pools
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun

item.content:encoded: Extensive harvesting of marine life at San Pedro's White Point Beach has 'decimated' the ecosystem, says Los Angeles City Atty. Mike Feuer.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO, CA - JULY 07: Doug Wall, game warden with the California Department of Fish and Wildlife, confiscates bags of mussels collected without a license at White Point in San Pedro. Beginning about a month ago, scores of people began scouring the tidepools at this location with nearby residents complaining that these excursions have gotten out of hand after lockdown orders were lifted. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: DIY air filters can be safe, simple and inexpensive. Here's how to make one
item.dc:creator: Ada Tseng
item.description: If air purifiers are sold out or out of your budget, a simple air filter taped to a box fan can filter harmful particulate matter and keep it out of your lungs and bloodstream. Here's what you need to know.
item.content:encoded: If air purifiers are sold out or out of your budget, a simple air filter taped to a box fan can filter harmful particulate matter and keep it out of your lungs and bloodstream. Here's what you need to know.

media:content.media:description: Thomas Talhelm, center, founder of Smart Air, led workshops when he was living in Beijing to demonstrate how to make a simple DIY air purifier that would protect users from breathing in dangerous particulate matter when there was poor air quality.

SEPTEMBER 15, 2020 -- Sheriff Deputies surround a home on Carlin Avenue in Compton, where Deonte Murray, 36, who is accused in the carjacking of a 51-year-old man who was shot in the leg with a high-powered rifle, was taken into custody, Tuesday September 15, 2020. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Californians who contract COVID-19 at work get additional help under new law
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: New California law makes it easier for police, firefighters and other essential workers who get COVID on the job to obtain workers' comp benefits.
item.content:encoded: New California law makes it easier for police, firefighters and other essential workers who get COVID on the job to obtain workers' comp benefits.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG.5, 2020. Grocery workers associated with UFCW Local 770 demonstrate Wednesday, Aug. 5, 2020, outside a Food 4 Less store in Los Angeles where 28 workers have allegedly become infected with COVID-19. The demonstrators called on Kroger, the parent company of Food 4 Less, to ensure safety measures in stores by providing regular COVID-19 testing, providing clear and timely information about infections and the inclusion of worker councils. (Luis Sinco/Los Aneles Time)

item.title: COVID-19 cases leap in outbreak at ICE detention center in Adelanto
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo
item.description: Several units at the facility are under quarantine as the number of those testing positive for the coronavirus more than doubled in the span of a few days.
item.content:encoded: Several units at the facility are under quarantine as the number of those testing positive for the coronavirus more than doubled in the span of a few days.

media:content.media:description: ADELANTO, CA - NOVEMBER 15: A guard escorts an immigrant detainee from his 'segregation cell' back into the general population at the Adelanto Detention Facility on November 15, 2013 in Adelanto, California. Most detainees in segregation cells are sent there for fighting with other immigrants, according to guards. The facility, the largest and newest Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), detention center in California, houses an average of 1,100 immigrants in custody pending a decision in their immigration cases or awaiting deportation. The average stay for a detainee is 29 days. The facility is managed by the private GEO Group. ICE detains an average of 33,000 undocumented immigrants in more than 400 facilities nationwide. (Photo by John Moore/Getty Images)

item.title: One of two deputies shot in Compton attack released from hospital
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: A 24-year-old male deputy shot in the head Saturday is out of the hospital but 'has a long road ahead for recovery,' Sheriff Alex Villanueva said.
item.content:encoded: A 24-year-old male deputy shot in the head Saturday is out of the hospital but 'has a long road ahead for recovery,' Sheriff Alex Villanueva said.

media:content.media:description: LYNWOOD, CA - SEPTEMBER 12: A large number of Sheriff's deputies stand gaurd outside St. Francis Medical Center where two L.A. County sheriff's deputies are being treated for after being shot and gravely injured in attack, after St. Francis Medical Center's security reported what they thought to be protesters on the property on Saturday, Sept. 12, 2020 in Lynwood, CA (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: For decades, activists got free rent from a leftist landlord. His son is putting a stop to it
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano
item.description: For 31 years, a parade of progressive nonprofit tenants didn't have to pay rent to a millionaire Marxist. Then he died and his son wants them out.
item.content:encoded: For 31 years, a parade of progressive nonprofit tenants didn't have to pay rent to a millionaire Marxist. Then he died and his son wants them out.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, CA - SEPTEMBER 16: Carol Wells of the Center for Study of Political Graphics, one of the tenants of the Peace Center in Culver City, has sued to stop the evictions and planned sale of the building. She has one of the largest collections of political posters including this poster of the Abu Ghraib abuses that mimics an Apple ad. Photographed at Peace Center on Wednesday, Sept. 16, 2020 in Culver City, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Why we made a Chicano Moratorium project zine

item.description: In August, the Los Angeles Times published a series on the 50th anniversary of the Chicano Moratorium antiwar demonstration. After an overwhelming response, most of the series will be collected in a 36-page zine.
item.content:encoded: In August, the Los Angeles Times published a series on the 50th anniversary of the Chicano Moratorium antiwar demonstration. After an overwhelming response, most of the series will be collected in a 36-page zine.

item.content:encoded: California appears to be riding a wave of success beating back the coronavirus. But these signs of progress also bring concerns that it could be erased.

California fitness centers have filed a lawsuit alleging Gov. Gavin Newsom's measures aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus unfairly target the industry and are demanding they be allowed to reopen. (AP Photo/Chris Pizzello)

item.title: How disaster relief has adapted to two horrors: Wildfires and coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Maria L. La Ganga
item.description: As wildfires rage in the West and hurricanes pummel the Gulf Coast during a pandemic, disaster aid has been forced to evolve, for better or worse.
item.content:encoded: As wildfires rage in the West and hurricanes pummel the Gulf Coast during a pandemic, disaster aid has been forced to evolve, for better or worse.

media:content.media:description: Oroville, California-SEPT. 16, 2020-James Wood, Red Cross Disaster Services volunteer, delivers meals to evacuees at the Motel 6 in Oroville, CA. Wood is there to deliver meals to evacuees staying at the motel. At the Motel 6 in Oroville, California, evacuees from Berry Creek and other areas effected by the North Complex fires are staying with the assistance of the Red Cross. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County mayors call on governor to let Disneyland and Knott's reopen
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: Disneyland, Knott's Berry Farm and other California theme parks have been shut for six months. An unusual set of circumstances in Orange County has led three mayors to demand a change.
item.content:encoded: Disneyland, Knott's Berry Farm and other California theme parks have been shut for six months. An unusual set of circumstances in Orange County has led three mayors to demand a change.

media:content.media:description: ANAHEIM, CA., MARCH 13, 2020: People walk towards the entrance of Disneyland Park on Fri., March 13, 2020 in Anaheim, CA. Disney's theme parks, Disneyland and California Adventure are closing due to precautions taken to prevent the spread of the Coronavirus. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Kent Nishimura/Kent Nishimura/Kent Nishimura/Kent Nishimura/Kent Nishimura/Kent Nishimura

item.title: Column One: Marijuana seller's story of 'badass' Mexican sisters was a cultural misstep, Latinas say
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda
item.description: Susie Plascencia and Savina Monet weren't going to let La Chingona cannabis get away with cultural appropriation.
item.content:encoded: Susie Plascencia and Savina Monet weren't going to let La Chingona cannabis get away with cultural appropriation.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 20, 2020 - - Reporter and multimedia journalist Susie Plascencia uncovered that La Chingona Canabis' bio had been fabricated and the company was owned mostly by white men who are being accused of culturally appropriating Mexican culture. They presented La Chingona Cannabis as a rarity in the cannabis industry stating it was a woman-owned, Latinx business built with traditional medicinal techniques that the founders, three sisters from Guadalajara, Mexico, learned from their grandmother and generations past. But it was all a lie. So Plascencia and Freelance Cannabis Designer Savina Monet, from Oregon, started a social media boycott, #ChingalaChingona, to bring the truth to light and hold the company accountable for deceiving the cannabis and Mexican-American communities. The owner now claims the company has dismantled due to their efforts. Plasencia was photographed at El Pueblo de Los Angeles on August 20, 2020. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Empty trucks, falsified records: How Louis DeJoy's changes at the Postal Service brought chaos
item.dc:creator: Maya Lau, Laura J. Nelson
item.description: New rules requiring U.S. Postal Service trucks to leave exactly on schedule went relatively unnoticed amid the public outcry over the removal of sorting machines across the country — but they were far more disruptive to mail delivery.
item.content:encoded: New rules requiring U.S. Postal Service trucks to leave exactly on schedule went relatively unnoticed amid the public outcry over the removal of sorting machines across the country — but they were far more disruptive to mail delivery.

media:content.media:description: VAN NUYS, CA - SEPTEMBER 09: Mail carriers load their trucks at the United States Postal Service (USPS) located at 15701 Sherman Way in Van Nuys, California on the morning of September 9, 2020. The USPS may be experiencing delays. U.S. Postal Service on Wednesday, Sept. 9, 2020 in Van Nuys, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

They are in a structure in a homeless community on "The Field," which is an area along the LA River on federal land. The majority of the people who live there use crystal meth.

item.title: Standoff in Lynwood ends with carjacking suspect in custody, not gunman in deputy ambush
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth, Leila Miller
item.description: Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies took into custody a carjacking suspect late Tuesday, ending a nearly nine-hour standoff in Lynwood rife with speculation that the Sheriff's Department had cornered the gunman who shot two deputies at point-blank range four days earlier.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies took into custody a carjacking suspect late Tuesday, ending a nearly nine-hour standoff in Lynwood rife with speculation that the Sheriff's Department had cornered the gunman who shot two deputies at point-blank range four days earlier.

media:content.media:description: Sheriff Deputies surround a home on Carlin Avenue in Compton. A manhunt continued today for the gunman who shot two Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies as they sat in a patrol SUV at a Compton rail station, with a reward for information leading to the suspect increasing to more than $200,000. Sheriff Alex Villanueva said investigators had ``promising leads'' and hoped to have something to announce soon. ``We're on the right path,'' Villanueva told multiple media outlets Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: Ransomware attack hits Newhall schools, halting online classes

item.content:encoded: A ransomware attack at the Newhall School District over the weekend has put online learning on hold for roughly 6,000 students.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Aug. 22, 2019, file photo, signs on a bank of computers tell visitors that the machines are not working at the public library in Wilmer, Texas. Some cybersecurity professionals are concerned that insurance policies designed to limit the damage of ransomware attacks might actually be encouraging hackers. Twenty-two local governments in Texas were hit in August. (AP Photo/Tony Gutierrez, File)

item.title: Tens of thousands of L.A. area students still need computers or Wi-Fi 6 months into pandemic
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel, Howard Blume
item.description: The digital divide still harms tens of thousands of L.A. students still without computers and internet access when they must learn online.
item.content:encoded: The digital divide still harms tens of thousands of L.A. students still without computers and internet access when they must learn online.

media:content.media:description: MAR VISTA, CA - JULY 13, 2020 - - Pedestrians walk past the Grand View Boulevard Elementary School with a marquee that still reads, "No School," in Mar Vista on July 13, 2020. Los Angeles campuses will not reopen for classes on Aug. 18, and the nation's second-largest school system will continue with online learning until further notice, because of the worsening coronavirus surge, Supt. Austin Beutner announced Monday. "Let me be crystal clear," Beutner said in an interview with The Times. "We all know the best place for students to learn is in a school setting." But, he said, "We're going in the wrong direction. And as much as we want to be back at schools and have students back at schools - can't do it until it's safe and appropriate." (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. officials warn against lifting COVID-19 restrictions until a review of Labor Day weekend data
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: California's COVID-19 case count and hospitalizations are declining, but L.A. County officials won't budge on lifting restrictions, fearing reversal.
item.content:encoded: California's COVID-19 case count and hospitalizations are declining, but L.A. County officials won't budge on lifting restrictions, fearing reversal.

item.title: FBI arrests drug ring that also sold 'ghost gun' AR-15s
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Authorities arrested 18 people identified in a series of federal indictments with links to a Southern California drug ring that also sold illegal weapons.
item.content:encoded: Authorities arrested 18 people identified in a series of federal indictments with links to a Southern California drug ring that also sold illegal weapons.

media:content.media:description: Jack Bennett, acting assistant director of the FBI Los Angeles field office, announces federal charges against 25 defendants accused of illegal drugs and firearms offenses at a news conference in Los Angeles, Tuesday, Sept. 15, 2020. (AP Photo/Stefanie Dazio)

item.title: So much at stake as firefighters battle to save historic Mt. Wilson Observatory
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith, Louis Sahagun, Thomas Curwen
item.description: The Bobcat fire is threatening the observatory, which has played host to Albert Einstein, Stephen Hawking and Edwin Hubble in its century-long history.
item.content:encoded: The Bobcat fire is threatening the observatory, which has played host to Albert Einstein, Stephen Hawking and Edwin Hubble in its century-long history.

media:content.media:description: A five ton mirror is carried on a truck for a telescope on the Mount Wilson Observatory July 1, 1917.

item.title: LAPD Chief Moore points to pandemic as driving factor in increased gun violence, killings
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: LAPD Chief Michel Moore said the COVID-19 pandemic has helped drive gun violence this year, including by spurring economic despair.
item.content:encoded: LAPD Chief Michel Moore said the COVID-19 pandemic has helped drive gun violence this year, including by spurring economic despair.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- MONDAY, JANUARY 28, 2019: LAPD Chief Michel Moore announces that for the first time in five years, violent crime was down in Los Angeles in 2018, with the number of homicides on track to be among the lowest in more than 50 years during a press conference at LAPD headquarters in Los Angeles, Calif., on Jan. 28, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Column: We don't know much about the ambush of 2 L.A. County deputies. But we have scapegoats
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: The man who shot two L.A. County deputies probably hates cops, but that doesn't justify dismissing police reform and the racial justice movement.
item.content:encoded: The man who shot two L.A. County deputies probably hates cops, but that doesn't justify dismissing police reform and the racial justice movement.

media:content.media:description: LYNWOOD, CA - SEPTEMBER 12: Sheriff Alex Villanueva holds a press conference outside the emergency room of St. Francis Medical Center where two L.A. County sheriff's deputies are being treated for after being shot and gravely injured in attack captured on Saturday, Sept. 12, 2020 in Lynwood, CA (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Vanessa Bryant slams L.A. County sheriff for challenging LeBron James to match reward
item.dc:creator: Chuck Schilken
item.description: LeBron James hasn't responded to Alex Villanueva's challenge to double reward money for information on two deputies' shooting. But Vanessa Bryant has.
item.content:encoded: LeBron James hasn't responded to Alex Villanueva's challenge to double reward money for information on two deputies' shooting. But Vanessa Bryant has.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this March 4, 2018, file photo, Kobe Bryant, right, and his wife Vanessa Bryant arrive at the Oscars at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles. Kobe Bryant's widow Vanessa Bryant has sued the owner of the helicopter that crashed in fog and killed her husband and her 13-year-old daughter last month. The wrongful death lawsuit filed by Vanessa Bryant in Los Angeles says the pilot was careless and negligent by flying in cloudy conditions and should have aborted the flight. The pilot was among the nine people killed in the crash. The lawsuit was filed as a public memorial service for Kobe Bryant and his daughter was being held at the arena where Bryant played most of his career.(Photo by Jordan Strauss/Invision/AP, File)

item.title: 15 fatalities confirmed. North Complex now among state's top 5 deadliest fires
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Another fatality is confirmed in the North Complex fire, raising the fire's death toll to 15. In recorded state history, only four fires have been deadlier.
item.content:encoded: Another fatality is confirmed in the North Complex fire, raising the fire's death toll to 15. In recorded state history, only four fires have been deadlier.

media:content.media:description: Firefighters search through a burned residence after the passage of the Bear fire, part of the larger North Lightning Complex fire, in the Berry Creek area of unincorporated Butte county, California on September 14, 2020. - President Donald Trump on September 14, 2020 suggested global warming will reverse itself and dismissed climate change as a cause of ferocious fires engulfing swaths of the US West, during a briefing in California on the deadly blazes. (Photo by JOSH EDELSON / AFP) (Photo by JOSH EDELSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.content:encoded: A proposed desalination plant along Monterey Bay is one of the most complicated and fraught issues to come before the California Coastal Commission.

item.title: 'Been shot in the head': Deputies' struggle to survive after Compton attack
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Two L.A. County deputies are recovering after being shot at close range. How did they survive?
item.content:encoded: Two L.A. County deputies are recovering after being shot at close range. How did they survive?

media:content.media:description: Sheriff Deputies surround a home on Carlin Avenue in Compton. A manhunt continued today for the gunman who shot two Los Angeles County sheriff's deputies as they sat in a patrol SUV at a Compton rail station, with a reward for information leading to the suspect increasing to more than $200,000. Sheriff Alex Villanueva said investigators had ``promising leads'' and hoped to have something to announce soon. ``We're on the right path,'' Villanueva told multiple media outlets Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: L.A. community colleges will remain online-only through spring

item.title: South L.A. activists seek dialogue with Sheriff's Department after deputy shooting inflames tensions
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Prominent South L.A. community activist Najee Ali denounced violence and offered prayers for injured sheriff's deputies
item.content:encoded: Prominent South L.A. community activist Najee Ali denounced violence and offered prayers for injured sheriff's deputies

media:content.media:description: LYNWOOD, CA - SEPTEMBER 14, 2020 - - Najee Ali, director of Project Islamic Hope, raises praying hands after giving Los Angeles Sheriff Sgt. Larry Villareal flowers and a "get well" balloon for the two sheriff deputies who were recovering from being shot in an ambush at the St. Francis Medical Center in Lynwood on September 14, 2020. Two Los Angeles County Sheriff Deputies are in critical condition after being shot in an ambush outside the Compton Metro train station last Saturday night. Ali held a press conference condemning the shooting. "We're here to pray for these officers for a full recovery," Ali said. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)
